fixes.title: Injected getFrameContext() via DI into element-locator, aria, click-executor
Document-wide role+name fallback in getElementByRef, inline re-resolution in executeJsClickOnRef and clickWithVerificationByRef
Added waitForNetworkSettle() to page-controller, wired into step-executors after navigation and before snapshot
Shadow DOM ref re-resolution with shadow host path traversal
Auto-scope snapshots to <main> element when no root specified. Reduces footer/boilerplate noise. Gate failed because only 10/30 tests were run (new tests only).

improvements.title: Frame context doesn't persist across CLI invocations
symptoms: Call switchToFrame, next CLI call reverts to main frame
listFrames shows currentFrameId back to mainFrameId
improvements.expected: Frame context should persist with tab session

improvements.title: Hover doesn't support coordinates
symptoms: {"hover": {"x": 100, "y": 200}} not supported
Cannot trigger hover on shadow DOM elements without selector
improvements.expected: Hover should accept x/y coordinates

improvements.title: Key presses in dialogs don't reach input fields
symptoms: Open Monaco Go to Line dialog with Ctrl+G, press number keys - they don't appear in input
Keys may be going to wrong element
improvements.expected: Key presses should reach the focused input in dialogs

improvements.title: Selection lost when clicking toolbar buttons
symptoms: Select text in WYSIWYG editor with Shift+Arrow
Click Bold button - selection is lost before formatting applies
improvements.expected: Option to preserve selection during click

improvements.title: Keyboard shortcuts with modifiers don't trigger SPA event handlers
symptoms: Meta+k dispatches keydown but doesn't trigger GitHub command palette
Shortcut works manually in Chrome but not via CDP
SPA applications listen at document level, CDP events may not trigger listeners
improvements.expected: Keyboard shortcuts with modifiers should trigger same handlers as physical presses
improvements.workaround: Click the button that triggers the same action

improvements.title: Invalid CSS selector doesn't show parsing error
symptoms: {"click": "[[[invalid"} times out instead of immediate error
No indication that selector syntax is invalid
improvements.expected: Immediate error like 'Invalid CSS selector'

improvements.title: Silent exit code 1 without JSON output
symptoms: Some failures return exit code 1 with no stdout/stderr
Hard to debug what went wrong
improvements.expected: Always return JSON with error details

improvements.title: Error messages show duplicate information
symptoms: Error shows "(timeout: 0ms) (timeout: 30000ms)" - timeout reported twice
improvements.expected: Single, clear timeout message

improvements.title: Snapshot returns limited content on some React SPAs
symptoms: Airbnb page snapshot returns only 2 elements (Skip to content, alert)
Complex React SPAs with custom components have sparse accessibility trees
improvements.expected: Snapshot should capture full accessibility tree for React SPAs

improvements.title: captureResult delay too short for tooltips
symptoms: hover with captureResult returns visibleElements: []
100ms delay not enough for JS tooltips to render
improvements.expected: Make delay configurable or increase default

improvements.title: Snapshot shows tooltip role but no text content
symptoms: Snapshot shows '- tooltip' but not the tooltip text
improvements.expected: Include tooltip content in snapshot

improvements.title: Text selectors like button:has-text(...) timeout
symptoms: {"click": "button:has-text('Submit')"} times out
Button is visible in screenshot
Playwright-style :has-text() pseudo-selector not supported
improvements.expected: Support :has-text() pseudo-selector or similar text matching

improvements.title: Drag doesn't work on HTML5 range input sliders
symptoms: Drag returns {"dragged": true} but slider value doesn't change
Click-at-position on slider track works as workaround
improvements.expected: Drag should move the slider thumb and update the value
improvements.workaround: Use click-at-position on slider track or keyboard arrow keys

improvements.title: New tab detection/tracking when links open in new tabs
symptoms: Click a link that opens in new tab, navigated: false returned
No indication that new tab opened
Agent must call chromeStatus to discover the new tab
improvements.expected: Detect when click opens new tab, return info about new tab in response
improvements.workaround: Use chromeStatus after clicks that may open new tabs

improvements.title: getBoundingClientRect() returns empty object in eval
symptoms: eval with el.getBoundingClientRect() returns {}

improvements.title: Scroll reports incorrect position

improvements.expected: Scroll should report correct position after scrolling

improvements.title: Session state accumulation causes issues after extended use

improvements.title: Framework detection on page load
symptoms: Agents don't know what frameworks a page uses until they encounter issues
Early detection would allow proactive strategy adjustment
improvements.expected: Add framework detection to goto and openTab responses

improvements.title: Lazy selector resolution (eliminate stale refs)
symptoms: Cached element handles can become stale creating stale element errors
Re-resolving selector from scratch for every action would eliminate this class of errors
improvements.expected: Never cache element references, re-resolve selector for every action

improvements.title: MutationObserver-based waiting
symptoms: Polling at 100ms intervals is slower and uses more CPU than event-driven detection
improvements.expected: Use MutationObserver for real-time DOM change detection

improvements.title: XPath support
symptoms: Some DOM traversal patterns are awkward with CSS selectors
improvements.expected: Add XPath selector support alongside CSS

improvements.title: Innermost text matching
symptoms: Text matching can match parent elements containing same text as target child

improvements.expected: Filter text matches to return only innermost matching elements

improvements.title: Frame-scoped snapshots
symptoms: Large pages produce verbose snapshots
When target area is known, capturing only that portion improves efficiency

improvements.title: Closed shadow DOM piercing
symptoms: Cannot access closed shadow roots via normal DOM APIs
improvements.expected: Monkey-patch Element.attachShadow() to maintain WeakMap of closed shadow roots

improvements.title: Frame-aware element identification
symptoms: Element refs are scoped to single frame context, requiring manual frame switching
improvements.expected: Encode element IDs as frameOrdinal-backendNodeId pairs, support >> hop notation

improvements.title: Adaptive depth handling
symptoms: Hard depth limits truncate DOM capture with no automatic recovery
improvements.expected: Progressive depth reduction on encoder errors, re-hydrate missing branches

improvements.title: Refs map inlined in every snapshot response
symptoms: Every snapshot response includes full refs map as inline JSON (CSS selectors keyed by ref ID)
HN: ~20KB of CSS selectors. ECMAScript spec: exceeds 1MB

improvements.expected: Refs should be written to file or omitted from JSON entirely

improvements.title: Summary mode includes all refs inline
symptoms: Summary detail level includes ALL refs inline in JSON

Amazon product names duplicated in parent link + child heading

improvements.title: Viewport snapshot includes fixed/sticky navigation in every response
symptoms: ECMAScript spec: fixed TOC sidebar is ~60% of every viewport snapshot
Wikipedia: banner + nav bars repeat in every viewport snapshot
Same banner content processed 5 times in a 5-action workflow
improvements.expected: Option to exclude fixed/sticky elements or auto-detect and omit after first snapshot

improvements.title: Headings and non-interactive elements have no refs in snapshotSearch
symptoms: snapshotSearch returns ref=None for all heading matches
Wikipedia: all 11 section headings return ref=None

improvements.expected: Headings should get refs as they are navigation targets

improvements.title: Interactive detail level broken on link-dense pages
symptoms: HN: interactive (23,147 bytes) is LARGER than full (15,879 bytes)
Wikipedia: interactive saves only 12% vs full

improvements.expected: Interactive should always be strictly smaller than full

improvements.title: since hash ignores element state changes
symptoms: Checkbox toggles don't change the hash
snapshot with since falsely reports unchanged after toggling checkboxes

improvements.title: Combobox/select shows no value in snapshot
symptoms: select elements render as bare 'combobox [ref=s1e1]' with no selected value
After selecting Option 2, snapshot still shows just combobox
improvements.expected: Display like combobox "Option 2" [ref=s1e1] showing selected option

improvements.title: Table cell text missing in default snapshot
symptoms: td and th elements show as empty cell and columnheader without includeText

improvements.expected: Table cells should show text content by default

improvements.title: snapshotSearch fuzzy matching too aggressive
symptoms: 'star' matches 'start', 'started' etc. (no word-boundary awareness)
No relevance scoring, long commit messages rank equally with navigation links
improvements.expected: Default matching should use word boundaries, add fuzzy parameter for control

improvements.title: snapshotSearch results lack state attributes
symptoms: Checkbox search returns refs but doesn't indicate checked status

improvements.title: snapshotSearch path context unhelpful on large pages
symptoms: HN: all matches share identical path with no disambiguation
ECMAScript spec: all headings show path 'generic' with no section hierarchy

improvements.title: Unnamed buttons have no fallback text

improvements.title: Same-page anchor navigation causes full page reload
symptoms: goto with #hash fragment on same page causes full page reload

improvements.expected: Detect same-origin URL with only hash difference and use location.hash + scroll

symptoms: GitHub search input placeholder reported as context.modal on every page load

improvements.title: selectOption produces no diff/changes

Unlike click and fill, selectOption generates no diff

improvements.title: Text-based click silently matches wrong element
symptoms: click with text 'History' matched navigation link instead of article heading
No disambiguation warning despite multiple matches

improvements.title: HTML markup leaking into accessible names

improvements.title: Page reload invalidates CDP session with no recovery
symptoms: reload destroys CDP session entirely

improvements.expected: Auto-reconnect to same tab after page reload

improvements.title: Reconnect step for session recovery
symptoms: After session disconnect, no way to re-attach to same tab

improvements.expected: Add reconnect step that tries to re-attach by URL pattern or tab ID

improvements.title: Composite clickAndSnapshot step
symptoms: Click + snapshot is the most common two-step pattern
Requires two CLI invocations adding latency
improvements.expected: Add clickAndSnapshot that performs both in one invocation

improvements.title: waitForSettled step (DOM mutation quiet)
symptoms: After page loads or complex UI transitions, unclear what to wait for
wait requires knowing a specific selector or text
No way to say 'wait until the page stops changing'
improvements.expected: waitForSettled step that waits for no DOM mutations for N milliseconds

improvements.title: Auto-learning from failures
symptoms: Site profiles are entirely manual, agent must remember to call writeSiteProfile
Quirks discovered during sessions are lost if not explicitly recorded
Same failure patterns repeat across sessions
improvements.expected: Auto-append discovered quirks to site profile after failures

improvements.title: Clicking hidden radio/checkbox inputs via refs reports 'ok' status with a warnin
symptoms: Clicking hidden radio/checkbox inputs via refs reports 'ok' status with a warning about visibility, but does NOT actually toggle the input state. The click appears to succeed from the response but has no effect. This is misleading - either the click should actually work (e.g., by automatically clicking the associated label), or it should report a clearer failure indicating the input was not toggled. On demoqa.com, radio buttons and checkboxes use hidden inputs with visible CSS-styled labels, which is an extremely common pattern across modern web frameworks.

improvements.title: TinyMCE editor on the-internet.herokuapp.com is permanently in read-only mode du
symptoms: TinyMCE editor on the-internet.herokuapp.com is permanently in read-only mode due to expired Tiny Cloud API key. The console shows 'All created TinyMCE editors are configured to be read-only' and 'you have no more editor loads available this month'. This means the test cannot be completed via normal user interaction (switchToFrame + fill/type). The only way to set content is via direct DOM manipulation through pageFunction, which bypasses the editor's read-only restriction. This test should either use a self-hosted TinyMCE instance without cloud licensing, or the test expectations should acknowledge that DOM manipulation is the expected approach.

improvements.title: Snapshot returns empty YAML inside frameset frames
symptoms: After switching to frame-left (a frame inside a frameset), snapshot returned {yaml: '', refs: {}}. The accessibility tree may not properly traverse frameset-based frames. Had to use pageFunction as fallback to read text content.

improvements.title: No native file upload support - had to use pageFunction with Dropzone API
symptoms: cdp-skill fill step rejects file inputs as 'not editable'. Had to use pageFunction to call Dropzone.forElement().addFile() to programmatically upload. CDP protocol supports DOM.setFileInputFiles which could be exposed as a dedicated step (e.g., 'uploadFile' or 'setFileInput') for native file upload support without requiring pageFunction workarounds.
improvements.workaround: cdp-skill fill step rejects file inputs as 'not editable'. Had to use pageFunction to call Dropzone.forElement().addFile() to programmatically upload. CDP protocol supports DOM.setFileInputFiles which could be exposed as a dedicated step (e.g., 'uploadFile' or 'setFileInput') for native file upload support without requiring pageFunction workarounds.

improvements.title: Used CSS selector instead of ref after ref-based click failed
symptoms: After two failed attempts to click via ref s1e12, used CSS selector 'table tbody tr:nth-of-type(5) td:nth-of-type(7) a:first-of-type' which succeeded via jsClick-auto fallback. Refs from earlier snapshots should remain valid and clickable regardless of scroll position.
improvements.workaround: After two failed attempts to click via ref s1e12, used CSS selector 'table tbody tr:nth-of-type(5) td:nth-of-type(7) a:first-of-type' which succeeded via jsClick-auto fallback. Refs from earlier snapshots should remain valid and clickable regardless of scroll position.

improvements.title: Time list items outside viewport require force click
symptoms: The react-datepicker time list is a scrollable container where most items are outside the browser viewport. Using ref click failed with 'Coordinates must be non-negative' and jsClick also failed with 'outside viewport'. Had to use force:true which fell back to jsClick-fallback. The scrollUntilVisible option could help but it scrolls the page, not the internal container.
improvements.workaround: The react-datepicker time list is a scrollable container where most items are outside the browser viewport. Using ref click failed with 'Coordinates must be non-negative' and jsClick also failed with 'outside viewport'. Had to use force:true which fell back to jsClick-fallback. The scrollUntilVisible option could help but it scrolls the page, not the internal container.

improvements.title: Multiselect input click needed jsClick fallback
symptoms: Clicking the multiselect input (ref s1e8) required jsClick-auto fallback because the CDP click was intercepted. The auto-fallback handled this transparently.
improvements.workaround: Clicking the multiselect input (ref s1e8) required jsClick-auto fallback because the CDP click was intercepted. The auto-fallback handled this transparently.

improvements.title: Using refs avoids selector escaping complexity
symptoms: When dealing with complex selectors containing quotes or special characters, taking a snapshot first and using refs (e.g., s1e9) is more reliable and easier than managing shell/JSON escaping for data-test attributes.
improvements.workaround: When dealing with complex selectors containing quotes or special characters, taking a snapshot first and using refs (e.g., s1e9) is more reliable and easier than managing shell/JSON escaping for data-test attributes.

improvements.title: Click step errors even when navigation succeeds
symptoms: In call #5, the fill succeeded and triggered form submission/navigation to /secure, but the click step reported an error 'CDP error: Cannot find context with specified id'. The navigation was successful and the page landed on the secure area, but the click step status was marked as error.

improvements.title: Direct section navigation more reliable than search
symptoms: For topic-based searches on Al Jazeera, directly navigating to topical sections (e.g., /climate-crisis, /middle-east) is more reliable than using the site's search functionality. This avoids search result loading issues and reduces steps.
improvements.workaround: For topic-based searches on Al Jazeera, directly navigating to topical sections (e.g., /climate-crisis, /middle-east) is more reliable than using the site's search functionality. This avoids search result loading issues and reduces steps.

improvements.title: Used pageFunction to extract full page text (innerText.substring(0, 5000)) as a
symptoms: Used pageFunction to extract full page text (innerText.substring(0, 5000)) as a reliable way to get structured recipe data including serving size and ingredients. This was more efficient than multiple scroll + snapshotSearch combinations for content-heavy recipe pages.
improvements.workaround: Used pageFunction to extract full page text (innerText.substring(0, 5000)) as a reliable way to get structured recipe data including serving size and ingredients. This was more efficient than multiple scroll + snapshotSearch combinations for content-heavy recipe pages.

improvements.title: Snapshot doesn't show state change after failed drag
symptoms: After the first drag attempt with mouse-events method (call 4), the viewportSnapshot still showed 'banner A' and 'banner B' even though visually the drag occurred. The snapshot didn't reflect that nothing actually changed in the DOM. This made it harder to diagnose that the drag didn't work.

improvements.title: getDom useful for understanding page mechanics
symptoms: Using getDom step to inspect the full page HTML revealed the JavaScript event handlers and HTML5 drag-and-drop implementation details. This helped identify that the page uses HTML5 DnD, not a custom drag library.
improvements.workaround: Using getDom step to inspect the full page HTML revealed the JavaScript event handlers and HTML5 drag-and-drop implementation details. This helped identify that the page uses HTML5 DnD, not a custom drag library.

improvements.title: buildVerifyCapture wraps eval_truthy expressions containing statements in !!() causing syntax errors
get step fails with 'Could not detect data type' for simple text extraction
symptoms: Both `{"get":"#finish h4"}` and `{"get":{"selector":"#finish h4","mode":"text"}}` fail with 'Could not detect data type. Use type: "table" or "list" option.' The error message suggests it's trying to auto-detect a data format when mode:'text' should simply extract textContent. The mode parameter appears to be completely ignored. This forces users to fall back to pageFunction for basic text extraction, which defeats the purpose of having a get step.

improvements.title: fill reports success but value does not persist in fullscreen overlay search inputs
symptoms: When filling the allrecipes.com fullscreen search overlay input (#mntl-fullscreen-nav__search__search-input), the fill step reports status 'ok' but the input's value property remains empty string when checked via pageFunction. This happened twice - first with input[name=q] and then with the expanded overlay input. The fill action appears to dispatch events but the value does not stick, possibly due to the site's JS framework resetting the input or the overlay being a React-controlled component that discards programmatic value changes. The workaround was to navigate directly to the search URL.

improvements.title: drag with method:'auto' defaults to mouse-events which fails on HTML5 DnD sites
symptoms: The 'auto' method (default) for drag chose 'mouse-events' on the-internet.herokuapp.com/drag_and_drop, which uses the HTML5 Drag and Drop API. The drag step reported success (dragged: true) but the elements did NOT actually swap. Only when explicitly using method:'html5' did the drag work correctly. The 'auto' method should detect HTML5 DnD attributes (draggable='true', ondragstart handlers) and automatically select the html5 method. Additionally, the step should not report dragged:true when the drag had no visible effect - this is a misleading success response.

improvements.title: fill reports success but value does not persist in fullscreen overlay search inputs

The fill action appears to dispatch events but the value does not stick, possibly due to the site's JS framework resetting the input or the overlay being a React-controlled component that discards programmatic value changes. The workaround was to navigate directly to the search URL.

Additionally, the step should not report dragged:true when the drag had no visible effect - this is a misleading success response.

feedback.detail: Site profile for allrecipes.com correctly identified search textbox name=q, which allowed filling via ref after clicking search button. Profile was concise and helpful.

feedback.detail: Click on search result card (s2e8) required jsClick-auto fallback. CDP click was intercepted, likely by an overlay or ad element. The auto-fallback worked seamlessly.

feedback.detail: drag step with default method 'auto' used mouse-events which failed to trigger HTML5 drag-and-drop on the-internet.herokuapp.com. The 'auto' method should detect HTML5 draggable attribute and prefer html5 method when present. Required explicit method='html5' to succeed.

feedback.detail: Amazon product link click required jsClick-auto fallback. CDP click was intercepted, likely by an overlay or event handler on the search results grid. The site profile should note that product links on search results pages may need jsClick.

feedback.title: Slider interaction via click-to-focus then ArrowRight key presses is reliable. T
feedback.detail: Slider interaction via click-to-focus then ArrowRight key presses is reliable. The ref-based click (s1e1) correctly focused the input[type=range] element, and each ArrowRight press incremented the value by a consistent step. The #range span updated automatically. This is a cleaner approach than drag for range inputs.

feedback.detail: Snapshot did not assign refs to img elements (User Avatar images), requiring CSS selector for hover. Consider assigning refs to img elements in snapshots for easier targeting.

feedback.title: CDP click on featured article ref s1e18 was intercepted by the OneTrust cookie c
feedback.detail: CDP click on featured article ref s1e18 was intercepted by the OneTrust cookie consent banner overlay, triggering automatic jsClick fallback. The cookie banner (modal 'Manage Your Privacy Choices') covered the click target. Dismissing the banner first would allow native CDP click to succeed.

feedback.title: archive.org returns empty accessibility snapshots with default detail mode; pier
feedback.detail: archive.org returns empty accessibility snapshots with default detail mode; pierceShadow:true with full detail is required to get usable element refs. Site profile correctly documents this quirk.

Site profile for daily.bandcamp.com was already available and provided accurate structural information about articles-list custom elements and the #p-daily-home container. The recipe suggesting direct navigation to daily.bandcamp.com was efficient.

The bandcamp.com homepage page navigation bar did not contain an 'Editorial' menuitem in headless mode (only Digital music, Vinyl, Compact discs, Cassettes, T-shirts, Gift cards). Direct goto to daily.bandcamp.com was the more reliable strategy than trying to find a navigation link.

feedback.title: Demoqa hides native radio and checkbox inputs (opacity:0, position:absolute) and
feedback.detail: Demoqa hides native radio and checkbox inputs (opacity:0, position:absolute) and uses styled labels as click targets. Clicking the hidden input refs (e.g. s1e8 for gender-radio-1) does not toggle the selection. Must click the label[for=...] selector instead. The cdp-skill auto-force mechanism clicks the hidden element but does not trigger the associated label behavior.

feedback.title: TinyMCE editor on the-internet.herokuapp.com is permanently in read-only mode du
feedback.detail: TinyMCE editor on the-internet.herokuapp.com is permanently in read-only mode due to Tiny Cloud API key exhaustion. The editor cannot be used normally via UI interactions (all toolbar buttons are disabled). Workaround: directly manipulate the iframe's contentDocument.body via pageFunction to set contentEditable and innerHTML. This bypasses the TinyMCE cloud blocking. The switchToFrame + fill approach would not work here because the editor body lacks standard input semantics when locked.

feedback.title: fillActive works well for contenteditable divs like Quill editors. Using fillAct
feedback.detail: fillActive works well for contenteditable divs like Quill editors. Using fillActive after clicking into the editor is more reliable than type with delay for rich text editors. The text was inserted as an H1 heading because the header:1 toolbar button was already active/pressed.

feedback.title: ProseMirror Home key does not reposition cursor in headless mode. Using Meta+a (
feedback.detail: ProseMirror Home key does not reposition cursor in headless mode. Using Meta+a (select all) is more reliable for selecting text in contenteditable editors than Home + Shift+ArrowRight sequences.

feedback.title: ProseMirror uses Mod-b for bold which maps to Meta+b on macOS, not Control+b. Th
feedback.detail: ProseMirror uses Mod-b for bold which maps to Meta+b on macOS, not Control+b. The site profile correctly documents this.

feedback.title: Site profile for microsoft.github.io correctly advised using Monaco API via page
feedback.detail: Site profile for microsoft.github.io correctly advised using Monaco API via pageFunction instead of standard fill/type for text entry. This strategy worked perfectly - model.setValue() set the content cleanly and Monaco automatically applied syntax highlighting (26 tokens detected).

feedback.title: Monaco editor virtual rendering means the accessibility snapshot code text lags
feedback.detail: Monaco editor virtual rendering means the accessibility snapshot code text lags behind API-driven changes until the editor area is clicked or focused. Clicking the editor ref after setValue ensures the viewport snapshot reflects the updated content.

feedback.title: TodoMVC React checkbox inputs are hidden by CSS and require force:true for direc
feedback.detail: TodoMVC React checkbox inputs are hidden by CSS and require force:true for direct CDP clicks. The initial non-forced click gave a warning 'Element exists but is not visible' and did not toggle the checkbox state. Using force:true resolved the issue.

feedback.title: The extract step with type=table cleanly parsed the HTML table into structured h
feedback.detail: The extract step with type=table cleanly parsed the HTML table into structured headers and rows, making data verification straightforward. Using extract before and after sorting was an efficient strategy to confirm the sort operation.

feedback.title: settledWhen with escaped quotes causes JSON parse errors
feedback.detail: Attempting to use settledWhen hooks with quoted CSS selectors inside the function string leads to JSON parse errors. The shell/JSON escaping becomes problematic. Workaround: use refs instead of selectors in click steps, or structure the command differently.

feedback.title: jsClick-auto fallback consistently used on saucedemo.com
feedback.detail: All click operations on buttons and links required automatic fallback to JavaScript click (jsClick-auto) after CDP click was intercepted. This suggests either the site's event handling or element positioning consistently blocks CDP native clicks.

feedback.title: Using refs avoids selector escaping complexity
feedback.detail: When dealing with complex selectors containing quotes or special characters, taking a snapshot first and using refs (e.g., s1e9) is more reliable and easier than managing shell/JSON escaping for data-test attributes.

feedback.title: Element refs do not persist across CLI invocations
feedback.detail: When using refs from a snapshot in the openTab response (s1e1, s1e2, s1e3), they are not found in subsequent CLI calls. Had to take a new snapshot to get working refs. This breaks the expected workflow where refs from navigation snapshots should be usable.

feedback.title: Click step errors even when navigation succeeds
feedback.detail: In call #5, the fill succeeded and triggered form submission/navigation to /secure, but the click step reported an error 'CDP error: Cannot find context with specified id'. The navigation was successful and the page landed on the secure area, but the click step status was marked as error.

feedback.title: Logout link required JS click fallback
feedback.detail: The logout link click (call #6) initially attempted CDP click but it was intercepted, so the system automatically fell back to JavaScript click which succeeded. The warning 'CDP click was intercepted, used JavaScript click fallback' appeared.

feedback.title: Al Jazeera search results not displaying
feedback.detail: After submitting a search query on aljazeera.com, the search results page loads (URL changes to /search/climate%20change) but no search results are displayed. The page only shows the search bar and footer. This may be due to JavaScript loading issues, CAPTCHA blocking, or headless detection. Workaround: navigate directly to topic sections like /climate-crisis instead of using search.

feedback.title: CDP click intercepted on article link
feedback.detail: When clicking the article link (s1e1), CDP click was intercepted and the system automatically fell back to jsClick. This worked successfully but adds overhead. Consider whether jsClick should be the default for article links on this site.

feedback.title: Direct section navigation more reliable than search
feedback.detail: For topic-based searches on Al Jazeera, directly navigating to topical sections (e.g., /climate-crisis, /middle-east) is more reliable than using the site's search functionality. This avoids search result loading issues and reduces steps.

feedback.title: The click on the recipe link (s1e3) succeeded but did not trigger immediate navi
feedback.detail: The click on the recipe link (s1e3) succeeded but did not trigger immediate navigation. Had to add explicit waitForNavigation step to complete the page load. This suggests potential timing issues with navigation detection after ref-based clicks.

feedback.title: Used pageFunction to extract full page text (innerText.substring(0, 5000)) as a
feedback.detail: Used pageFunction to extract full page text (innerText.substring(0, 5000)) as a reliable way to get structured recipe data including serving size and ingredients. This was more efficient than multiple scroll + snapshotSearch combinations for content-heavy recipe pages.

feedback.title: Default drag method fails for HTML5 drag-and-drop
feedback.detail: The default 'auto' method for drag operation uses 'mouse-events' which fails to trigger HTML5 drag-and-drop handlers. When dragging #column-a to #column-b without specifying method, the drag animation occurred but no swap happened. Only after explicitly setting method: 'html5' did the drag-and-drop work correctly.

feedback.title: Snapshot doesn't show state change after failed drag
feedback.detail: After the first drag attempt with mouse-events method (call 4), the viewportSnapshot still showed 'banner A' and 'banner B' even though visually the drag occurred. The snapshot didn't reflect that nothing actually changed in the DOM. This made it harder to diagnose that the drag didn't work.

feedback.title: getDom useful for understanding page mechanics
feedback.detail: Using getDom step to inspect the full page HTML revealed the JavaScript event handlers and HTML5 drag-and-drop implementation details. This helped identify that the page uses HTML5 DnD, not a custom drag library.

feedback.detail: Site profile for amazon.com was very helpful - provided stable selectors (#twotabsearchtextbox, #nav-search-submit-button) that worked perfectly without any trial and error

feedback.detail: Snapshot-based element references (s2e31) worked reliably for clicking product links, avoiding CSS selector brittleness

feedback.detail: The 'any' milestone condition allowed flexibility - URL contained both /dp/ (product page) and search worked as expected

feedback.detail: The pageFunction output format could be more intuitive. The nested structure (type: 'array', items: [{type: 'object', entries: {...}}]) adds verbosity. Consider flattening to return the direct array/object values.

feedback.title: Click action reported a new tab opened to demoqa.com (targetId 98DED30CA9291AC10
feedback.detail: Click action reported a new tab opened to demoqa.com (targetId 98DED30CA9291AC101A737B736225C96) even though we only intended to navigate to comments. This may have been from a background ad or popup that was unintended.

feedback.detail: Snapshot provided clear article structure with categories and titles, making extraction straightforward

feedback.title: Batch fill worked perfectly for name and email fields. Using {"#firstName": "Joh
feedback.detail: Batch fill worked perfectly for name and email fields. Using {"#firstName": "John", "#lastName": "Doe", "#userEmail": "john.doe@example.com"} is much more efficient than separate fill commands.

feedback.title: Gender radio button required clicking the label element [for="gender-radio-1"] i
feedback.detail: Gender radio button required clicking the label element [for="gender-radio-1"] instead of the actual radio input. This is a common pattern in DemoQA forms where radio buttons and checkboxes use label-based interaction.

feedback.title: The verification snapshot correctly captured all milestone states. Modal confirm
feedback.detail: The verification snapshot correctly captured all milestone states. Modal confirmation was properly verified using pageFunction to extract the textContent, which included 'Thanks for submitting the form'.

feedback.title: Initial attempt used {"wait": 2000} but this failed with validation error. The c
feedback.detail: Initial attempt used {"wait": 2000} but this failed with validation error. The correct syntax is {"sleep": 2000}. The error message was clear about the change, which helped immediate correction.

feedback.title: The TinyMCE editor is loaded in an iframe with read-only mode enforced by the cl
feedback.detail: The TinyMCE editor is loaded in an iframe with read-only mode enforced by the cloud API. The standard fill/type actions fail because the body element is not detected as contenteditable, even though it should be editable in a WYSIWYG editor.

feedback.title: Successfully recovered from the type action failure by using pageFunction as a f
feedback.detail: Successfully recovered from the type action failure by using pageFunction as a fallback. This demonstrates that the agent can adapt when standard actions don't work.

feedback.title: The test site (the-internet.herokuapp.com) uses TinyCloud API with monthly limit
feedback.detail: The test site (the-internet.herokuapp.com) uses TinyCloud API with monthly limits, causing the editor to be in read-only mode. This is a site-specific issue, not a skill issue.

feedback.title: The fill step successfully entered text into the focused Quill editor using the
feedback.detail: The fill step successfully entered text into the focused Quill editor using the simplified focused-element approach. The text was properly captured and rendered in the editor.

feedback.title: The click on .ql-editor required jsClick-auto fallback because CDP click was int
feedback.detail: The click on .ql-editor required jsClick-auto fallback because CDP click was intercepted. This is consistent with the site profile noting that Quill uses contenteditable elements. Future tests should expect this behavior.

feedback.title: The viewport snapshot shows the entered text rendered as a heading (level=1), wh
feedback.detail: The viewport snapshot shows the entered text rendered as a heading (level=1), which suggests Quill may have applied default formatting. This is expected behavior for Quill editors but worth noting for verification purposes.

feedback.title: The JS click fallback worked perfectly for focusing the contenteditable editor.
feedback.detail: The JS click fallback worked perfectly for focusing the contenteditable editor. The auto-fallback mechanism handled the interception gracefully without requiring manual intervention.

feedback.title: The sequence of Ctrl+A  fill  Home  Shift+End  Ctrl+B successfully cleared e
feedback.detail: The sequence of Ctrl+A  fill  Home  Shift+End  Ctrl+B successfully cleared existing content, inserted new text, and applied formatting. This pattern works reliably for contenteditable elements.

feedback.title: The eval_truthy verification correctly detected the presence of 'ProseMirror' te
feedback.detail: The eval_truthy verification correctly detected the presence of 'ProseMirror' text in the contenteditable element. The flexible OR condition (checking for both 'ProseMirror' and 'Testing') made the verification robust.

feedback.title: The site profile for microsoft.github.io correctly warned that Monaco Editor use
feedback.detail: The site profile for microsoft.github.io correctly warned that Monaco Editor uses virtual rendering and recommended using the Monaco API for text manipulation. This was critical - attempting to use standard 'type' or 'fill' steps would have failed. The pageFunction approach using monaco.editor.getModels()[0].setValue() worked perfectly.

feedback.title: The 'type' step validation could be clearer about its limitations with virtual e
feedback.detail: The 'type' step validation could be clearer about its limitations with virtual editors. When it failed with 'type requires selector', it wasn't immediately obvious that even with a selector, Monaco's virtual textarea wouldn't work. The error message after providing a selector ('Element is not editable') was more helpful.

feedback.title: The milestone verification for 'syntax_highlighted' checking for at least 3 mtk
feedback.detail: The milestone verification for 'syntax_highlighted' checking for at least 3 mtk tokens is well-designed and robust. The actual result (26 tokens) shows the editor is fully functional with proper syntax coloring.
Checkbox click required force:true due to visibility issue - element exists but reported as not visible on first attempt
Hover step with text parameter failed with 'ariaSnapshot.findByText is not a function' error
Had to use explicit selector instead of ref after hovering to reveal delete button, refs work well overall

feedback.title: Frame switching worked flawlessly for nested framesets. The {name: 'frame-name'}
feedback.detail: Frame switching worked flawlessly for nested framesets. The {name: 'frame-name'} syntax correctly switched to frames at both depth 1 and depth 2. No special navigation to parent frames was required - switching directly to 'frame-bottom' after being in 'frame-right' worked correctly.

feedback.title: The milestone verification for middle_frame_content and bottom_frame_content att
feedback.detail: The milestone verification for middle_frame_content and bottom_frame_content attempts to access frame.contentDocument from the main frame context, but this fails due to cross-origin restrictions (frames load from same domain but are treated as separate contexts). The verification should either switch into frames before checking content, or the test definition should acknowledge that cross-frame DOM access isn't possible.

feedback.title: The frame listing output with parentId and depth fields makes it trivial to unde
feedback.detail: The frame listing output with parentId and depth fields makes it trivial to understand the frameset hierarchy. No guessing required about which frames are nested inside which.

feedback.title: pageFunction successfully accessed shadow DOM using element.shadowRoot property
feedback.detail: pageFunction successfully accessed shadow DOM using element.shadowRoot property

feedback.title: Two-phase approach worked well: getDom to identify custom elements, then pageFun
feedback.detail: Two-phase approach worked well: getDom to identify custom elements, then pageFunction to access shadowRoot

feedback.title: Shadow roots use slots for content projection - light DOM content gets rendered
feedback.detail: Shadow roots use slots for content projection - light DOM content gets rendered into shadow DOM slots

feedback.title: Native JavaScript Dialog Handling Required
feedback.detail: The CDP skill lacks native support for handling JavaScript dialogs (alert, confirm, prompt). Currently, workarounds require overriding window.alert, window.confirm, and window.prompt functions via pageFunction before clicking buttons that trigger dialogs. This is error-prone and requires foreknowledge of dialog behavior.

feedback.title: Successful Dialog Override Pattern
feedback.detail: Successfully handled all three JavaScript dialog types by overriding window functions before interaction. The pattern works reliably: override alert/confirm/prompt to auto-respond, then click buttons that trigger them.

feedback.title: File upload requires manual pageFunction with DataTransfer API - no native step
feedback.detail: File upload requires manual pageFunction with DataTransfer API - no native step for file uploads

The `extract` step failed on a simple heading element (#finish h4) with error 'Could not detect data type'. For single text elements that aren't tables or lists, extract should fall back to text content extraction rather than requiring pageFunction.

feedback.title: Canvas text content cannot be extracted via DOM methods. Successfully worked aro
feedback.detail: Canvas text content cannot be extracted via DOM methods. Successfully worked around by reading the inline <script> tags that contain the canvas drawing code. This revealed 'Answer: 44698' from canvas.strokeText() call.

feedback.title: The edit link click required JavaScript fallback (jsClick-auto) - CDP click was
feedback.detail: The edit link click required JavaScript fallback (jsClick-auto) - CDP click was intercepted. This is likely due to the table layout or link positioning.

feedback.title: All 4 milestones passed successfully: table_present, table_data_readable, canvas
feedback.detail: All 4 milestones passed successfully: table_present, table_data_readable, canvas_present, and edit_link_accessible. The test accurately validates the challenging DOM features.

feedback.title: The selectOption step with refs fails when the calendar popup closes between sna
feedback.detail: The selectOption step with refs fails when the calendar popup closes between snapshot and selection. Using full CSS selectors works more reliably.

feedback.title: Using pageFunction to scroll and click time list items works perfectly when elem
feedback.detail: Using pageFunction to scroll and click time list items works perfectly when elements are outside viewport or when text matching is ambiguous.

feedback.title: React Select dropdowns work well with text-based clicking
feedback.detail: The React Select components on demoqa.com responded correctly to: (1) clicking the container to open, (2) clicking options by exact text match. The multiselect dropdown correctly maintained focus after each selection, allowing multiple selections without reopening.

feedback.title: Mixed select types require different strategies on same page
feedback.detail: This page contains three different select implementations: (1) React Select single-value dropdowns requiring click-to-open then click-option, (2) native HTML <select> requiring selectOption step, (3) React Select multiselect allowing multiple clicks before closing. Using the wrong approach for each type will fail.

feedback.title: React multiselect maintains open state between selections
feedback.detail: Unlike single-value React Select dropdowns that close immediately after selection, the multiselect variant keeps the dropdown open after each option click, allowing sequential selections without reopening. This enables efficient multi-selection workflows.

feedback.title: buildVerifyCapture wraps eval_truthy expressions containing statements in !!() causing syntax errors
Progress bar timing test requires sleep-based approach rather than polling
coordinate_validation
feedback.detail: The firstName field ([data-test="firstName"]) triggered a 'Coordinates must be non-negative' error during batch fill and ref-based fill. Had to scroll to top and use force:true to complete. This suggests an edge case in coordinate calculation for elements near viewport boundaries or after scroll.
Site profile for saucedemo.com was extremely helpful. The documented data-test attributes, React input handling, and jsClick fallback needs were accurate and saved significant debugging time.
The selectOption step worked flawlessly with native select element using value='lohi' to sort by price low to high. No issues with this interaction pattern.

fill step fails with 'Coordinates must be non-negative' when target element is above the visible viewport. After navigating to checkout-step-one.html, the page auto-scrolled to bottom (y=208, 100%). The fill step for [data-test=firstName] found the element but its getBoundingClientRect returned negative y coordinates since it was above the viewport. The fill actionability check should either auto-scroll the element into view before attempting to get coordinates, or handle negative coordinates gracefully by scrolling first. Currently requires a manual scroll+force workaround.

Every single click on saucedemo.com fell back to jsClick-auto (4 out of 4 clicks). The CDP click was consistently intercepted. While the auto-fallback works, this suggests CDP click may have a systematic issue with React-rendered elements on this site. The site profile notes this for cart buttons but it happened on ALL buttons including login, checkout, continue, and finish.

After logging in and adding Sauce Labs Backpack, the cart page showed Sauce Labs Onesie and Sauce Labs Bike Light instead. This indicates stale cart state from a previous session. The site profile mentions this quirk ('items from previous session may persist in cart'). For reliable testing, Reset App State via the burger menu should be called after login.

The `get` step fails with 'Could not detect data type. Use type: "table" or "list" option.' when targeting a simple div (#flash) both with bare string syntax (`{"get":"#flash"}`) and with explicit mode (`{"get":{"selector":"#flash","mode":"text"}}`). The mode:text parameter should extract text content from any element without trying to detect data types. This forces users to fall back to pageFunction for simple text extraction from non-standard elements.

When a form submit button click causes page navigation, the click step reports an error 'Cannot find context with specified id' even though the action succeeded. The navigation is confirmed by the response's navigated:true field and the new URL. This is a cosmetic issue - the step reports error status despite succeeding. The step could detect that a navigation occurred and treat it as success.

When the BBC menu is opened via the 'Open menu' button, the snapshot with root='nav' returns empty YAML with 0 interactive elements, even though the search input and navigation links are visible. The activeElement in the context correctly shows the search input, but the snapshot itself captures nothing. This may indicate a timing issue where the nav DOM hasn't fully rendered when the snapshot is taken, or the nav element selector doesn't match what BBC uses for its expanded menu. The workaround was to use the activeElement context info to identify the search input selector.

The click on the search result (s1e4) used jsClick-auto fallback ('CDP click was intercepted, used JavaScript click fallback'). This is expected behavior for BBC's Next.js SPA links, but worth noting that CDP click is consistently intercepted on this site.

feedback.title: fill reports success but value does not persist in fullscreen overlay search inputs
feedback.detail: When filling the allrecipes.com fullscreen search overlay input (#mntl-fullscreen-nav__search__search-input), the fill step reports status 'ok' but the input's value property remains empty string when checked via pageFunction. This happened twice - first with input[name=q] and then with the expanded overlay input. The fill action appears to dispatch events but the value does not stick, possibly due to the site's JS framework resetting the input or the overlay being a React-controlled component that discards programmatic value changes. The workaround was to navigate directly to the search URL.

feedback.title: jsClick-auto fallback fires frequently on allrecipes.com with no actual navigation
feedback.detail: Multiple clicks on allrecipes.com triggered jsClick-auto fallback (CDP click intercepted). The search icon click reported newTabs for unrelated URLs (herokuapp.com, demoqa.com) which appear to be from OTHER browser tabs, not actually opened by the click. The Pumpkin Soup link click also used jsClick-auto and reported navigated:false even though navigation did occur (confirmed by next step's context showing the recipe URL). The newTabs field reporting tabs from other sessions is misleading.

feedback.title: drag with method:'auto' defaults to mouse-events which fails on HTML5 DnD sites
feedback.detail: The 'auto' method (default) for drag chose 'mouse-events' on the-internet.herokuapp.com/drag_and_drop, which uses the HTML5 Drag and Drop API. The drag step reported success (dragged: true) but the elements did NOT actually swap. Only when explicitly using method:'html5' did the drag work correctly. The 'auto' method should detect HTML5 DnD attributes (draggable='true', ondragstart handlers) and automatically select the html5 method. Additionally, the step should not report dragged:true when the drag had no visible effect - this is a misleading success response.

CDP click on Amazon product listing link was intercepted (likely by overlay/dialog), triggering jsClick-auto fallback. The warning 'CDP click was intercepted, used JavaScript click fallback' appeared. This is expected behavior on Amazon where international shopping dialogs and overlays often intercept clicks, and the auto-fallback correctly handled it. The jsClick-auto mechanism is working as designed for sites with overlay interference.

The newTab step reported 2 phantom newTabs in its response (apnews.com and archive.org) that appear to be pre-existing tabs from other sessions, not tabs actually opened by the click on the search button. The click on #nav-search-submit-button should not create new tabs to unrelated domains.

feedback.title: The snapshot for the slider page does not display the #range element (output spa
feedback.detail: The snapshot for the slider page does not display the #range element (output span showing the slider value). The YAML accessibility snapshot shows the slider [ref=s1e1] but omits the adjacent <span id='range'> text node that displays the current value. This means an agent relying solely on the snapshot cannot see the current slider value without resorting to pageFunction or get. This might be because the span has no ARIA role and is treated as generic static text that gets filtered at summary/interactive detail levels.

feedback.title: Snapshot 'interactive' detail level does not assign refs to elements (only
feedback.detail: Snapshot 'interactive' detail level does not assign refs to elements (only links get refs). This means images cannot be targeted by ref for hover actions. The user must fall back to CSS selectors for hovering over images. Consider assigning refs to images as well since hover is a supported action on them.

feedback.title: The hover step successfully triggered CSS :hover state and revealed hidden figca
feedback.detail: The hover step successfully triggered CSS :hover state and revealed hidden figcaption content. The changes diff correctly detected the newly visible 'View profile' link and heading. This worked well.

feedback.title: CDP click on an in-page wiki link (anchor tag in a paragraph) was intercepted, f
feedback.detail:
CDP click on an in-page wiki link (anchor tag in a paragraph) was intercepted, falling back to jsClick-auto. This is a simple tag inside a

there should be no overlay or pointer-events issue. The auto-fallback works correctly but the CDP click interception on plain anchor links in body text on Wikipedia suggests the hit-test or pointer-events check may be overly sensitive. The element was fully visible and in-viewport.

feedback.title: Test 018-apnews expects url_matches 'apnews\.com/article/' but AP News homepage
feedback.detail: Test 018-apnews expects url_matches 'apnews\.com/article/' but AP News homepage top featured story is often a /live/ URL, not /article/. The test task says 'click on the top featured article' but the milestone requires /article/ in URL. Either the task description or the milestone URL pattern should be adjusted to match reality. This caused an extra back-navigation and fallback strategy during the test.

feedback.title: The cookie consent modal ('About Your Privacy') persisted across all page naviga
feedback.detail: The cookie consent modal ('About Your Privacy') persisted across all page navigations and was reported in context.modal on every response. The jsClick-auto fallback worked correctly to click through it, but a site profile strategy for dismissing the banner first would improve reliability. The auto-force/jsClick fallback pattern worked well here.

Snapshot returns completely empty YAML for archive.org homepage which uses shadow DOM (<app-root> with shadowRoot). The snapshot engine does not pierce shadow roots of custom elements by default, returning zero content. The pierceShadow option exists in the snapshot step API but is not enabled by default. For sites like archive.org that rely entirely on shadow DOM web components, the agent gets zero accessibility information from the default snapshot. Consider making pierceShadow default to true, or auto-detecting when the snapshot would be empty and retrying with shadow piercing.

The archive.org site profile says 'vanilla HTML, no SPA framework' and 'Fingerprint: vanilla HTML, no SPA framework' but the site actually uses web components with shadow DOM (<app-root> custom element). The profile was likely created based on the absence of React/Vue/Angular detection, but web component detection was not performed. The site profile is misleading and could cause agents to use wrong strategies.

The site profile for news.ycombinator.com was immediately available and accurately described the table-based layout, providing useful context. The siteProfile response field worked seamlessly without requiring an actionRequired flow.

The viewportSnapshot for the HN comments page is extremely large (many KB of inline YAML) because it includes full comment text. For text-heavy pages, the snapshot could benefit from a truncation or summarization mode to reduce response payload size. The inlineLimit config exists but the default seems generous for pages with large text content.

Click on the 'Explore more editorial' link (ref s1e24) fell back to jsClick-auto with warning 'CDP click was intercepted'. This is a simple anchor link on bandcamp.com homepage - the CDP click should have worked natively. The auto-fallback masks what could be a covering element or pointer-events issue worth investigating. While the fallback succeeded, the frequent jsClick-auto fallback on normal links may indicate the actionability checks are too strict or the covering-element detection is overzealous for elements that are perfectly clickable.

When clicking hidden radio/checkbox inputs via label-proxy on pages with ad overlays, the CDP native click on the label triggers ad navigation instead of toggling the input. The label-proxy click reported success (method: 'label-proxy') and even reported the gender radio as toggled, but the hobby checkboxes were NOT toggled despite identical label-proxy mechanism. The ad overlay <a> tags inside or near the label elements intercepted the native CDP click. The click executor should detect when a label-proxy click triggers navigation to an ad domain and retry with jsClick, or prefer jsClick for label-proxy interactions on pages with known ad content. This caused the need for manual retry steps with jsClick:true, adding 3 extra steps to what should have been a simple checkbox toggle.

The label-proxy click for the Male gender radio (s1e8) DID successfully toggle the radio despite also triggering an ad popup tab. This inconsistency between radio and checkbox label-proxy behavior on the same page with the same ad overlay suggests the bug may be timing-dependent or related to the specific DOM structure around each label element. The radio label may have been clicked in a spot that avoided the ad overlay, while the checkbox labels were fully covered.

feedback.title: When TinyMCE editor is in read-only mode (all buttons disabled), the snapshot's
feedback.detail: When TinyMCE editor is in read-only mode (all buttons disabled), the snapshot's document section does NOT show the iframe content after using setContent via pageFunction. The viewport snapshot still shows no 'Hello World' text even though the iframe body was successfully updated. This means the accessibility snapshot is not reflecting the current state of iframe content after programmatic changes - it likely caches the initial state or does not re-traverse iframe content. An agent relying solely on snapshots to verify iframe content changes would see stale data.

feedback.title: The TinyMCE test exposes a real-world scenario where a WYSIWYG editor is inside
feedback.detail: The TinyMCE test exposes a real-world scenario where a WYSIWYG editor is inside an iframe and in read-only mode. The cdp-skill handles this correctly via pageFunction accessing the parent window's TinyMCE API, but there's no built-in step for interacting with contentEditable elements inside iframes when the editor is API-locked. An agent must know to use the JS API rather than trying to fill/type into the editor.

feedback.title: Clicking .ql-editor on quilljs.com caused CDP click interception and auto-fallba
feedback.detail: Clicking .ql-editor on quilljs.com caused CDP click interception and auto-fallback to jsClick. The first .ql-editor element has a bounding box with x:-451 (off-screen left), which means the CSS selector matched an off-screen/hidden editor first. The click also unexpectedly opened a new tab to TodoMVC (https://todomvc.com/examples/react/dist/). This suggests the CDP click landed on a different element (possibly a link underneath) before the jsClick fallback reached the correct element. The skill should consider filtering .ql-editor candidates by visibility/viewport position when multiple matches exist.

feedback.title: The fill step with clear:false on a contenteditable div correctly appended text
feedback.detail: The fill step with clear:false on a contenteditable div correctly appended text in focused mode. However, it typed into the heading element (h1) rather than a paragraph, because the cursor happened to be in the heading after clicking. This is expected browser behavior but agents should be aware that contenteditable editors may have multiple child elements where cursor position matters.

feedback.title: When clicking on a ProseMirror contenteditable div, CDP click is intercepted and
feedback.detail: When clicking on a ProseMirror contenteditable div, CDP click is intercepted and falls back to jsClick-auto. This is expected behavior for contenteditable elements where the click target may be obscured by the editor framework's event handling layer. The warning 'CDP click was intercepted, used JavaScript click fallback' appears. Not a bug, but the auto-fallback mechanism is working as designed.

feedback.title: The fill step with clear:true on a contenteditable div (.ProseMirror) successful
feedback.detail: The fill step with clear:true on a contenteditable div (.ProseMirror) successfully cleared existing content and typed new text, but the text was placed inside an h3 tag rather than a plain paragraph. This is because the fill command cleared the content via select-all + delete which preserved the heading block structure from the original content. This is ProseMirror behavior rather than a cdp-skill bug, but agents should be aware that contenteditable editors may preserve block-level formatting even after clearing.

feedback.title: Ctrl+B bold toggle did not produce a <strong> tag when applied to text inside an
feedback.detail: Ctrl+B bold toggle did not produce a <strong> tag when applied to text inside an h3 heading in ProseMirror's basic schema. The selectText + press Ctrl+B sequence executed without error, but the DOM showed no bold formatting was applied. This may be a ProseMirror schema limitation (some schemas don't allow marks in headings) rather than a cdp-skill issue. Agents automating rich-text editors should verify formatting actually took effect after applying keyboard shortcuts.

feedback.title: When clicking a Monaco editor textbox ref (s1e2), the click warns 'Element exist
feedback.detail: When clicking a Monaco editor textbox ref (s1e2), the click warns 'Element exists but is not visible' because Monaco uses a zero-width native-edit-context div as the actual input. The click still succeeds but the warning could be confusing. The viewport snapshot also shows the code block element content but the textbox ref appears as a child  the accessibility tree could be more informative about the actual editable status of Monaco editors. This is not a bug per se, just a UX note about how virtual editors interact with the click actionability checks.

feedback.title: The viewport snapshot after clearing the editor (step 4) still showed the old co
feedback.detail: The viewport snapshot after clearing the editor (step 4) still showed the old code text '1const value = ...' in the accessibility tree code element, even though the Monaco model was confirmed empty. This is likely due to the snapshot being captured from a cached/stale accessibility tree before Monaco re-rendered. Not a cdp-skill bug  Monaco's accessibility tree updates asynchronously.

feedback.title: Clicking a ref for a hidden checkbox input (visibility:hidden or zero-size) via ref succeeds with a warning but does NOT actually toggle the checkbox. The click reports status:ok but the DOM state is unchanged. The auto-click-label feature (which is supposed to handle hidden radio/checkbox inputs per commit 9283cd5) did not activate when using a ref. Had to use force:true with a CSS selector to actually toggle the checkbox. This is a reliability gap: agents clicking refs for hidden checkboxes will silently fail.

feedback.detail: The `get` step with `{selector: '#table1 tbody', mode: 'text'}` returns error 'No table found'. The selector correctly targets a <tbody> element inside #table1, but the step appears to require the target element itself to be a <table>. This forces users to fall back to `pageFunction` for extracting text from table sub-elements like tbody, thead, or tr. The get step should extract text from any element matched by the selector, regardless of tag name.

When clicking '#table1 thead tr th:first-child span' (a span inside the th), the click succeeded but sorting did not occur. The click on the th directly with text:'Last Name' worked correctly. This suggests the span inside the th may not be a valid click target on this page, or the jQuery tablesorter plugin binds the click handler on the th element rather than its children. Not necessarily a bug in cdp-skill, but worth noting.

The `get` step with selector 'body' and mode 'text' fails with error 'Could not detect data type. Use type: table or list option' when used inside a frame context. The body element exists and has text content (verified via pageFunction), but the get step's data-type detection logic fails on it. This appears to be a bug in how the get step handles simple elements within frame contexts - it may be trying to auto-detect list/table structure and failing on a plain body element with just text content.

The milestone 'middle_frame_content' uses eval_truthy with document.querySelectorAll('frame') from the main frame, but the MIDDLE frame is nested inside frame-top (a frameset within a frameset). From the main frame, querySelectorAll('frame') only returns 2 direct children (frame-top, frame-bottom), not the nested frames (frame-left, frame-middle, frame-right). The verification should either navigate into the frame-top context first, or use window.frames[0].document.querySelectorAll('frame') to access the nested frames.

feedback.title: The pierceShadow snapshot option works correctly for this page - it reveals the
feedback.detail: The pierceShadow snapshot option works correctly for this page - it reveals the 'My default text' paragraphs inside shadow roots that are hidden without pierceShadow. However, the viewportSnapshot (which doesn't use pierceShadow) omits these paragraphs entirely. This is expected behavior but worth noting: agents relying only on viewportSnapshot will miss shadow DOM content. The SKILL.md troubleshooting section mentions 'Elements missing from snapshot' but could more explicitly recommend pierceShadow for shadow DOM pages.

feedback.title: No built-in JavaScript dialog (alert/confirm/prompt) handling
feedback.detail: The cdp-skill has no built-in support for handling native JavaScript dialogs (alert, confirm, prompt). CDP provides Page.javascriptDialogOpening events and Page.handleJavaScriptDialog commands for this purpose, but the skill doesn't listen for or handle these events. Page.enable is already called (page-controller.js:408), so dialog events would fire, but nothing handles them. Without the workaround of overriding window.alert/confirm/prompt via pageFunction, clicks that trigger native dialogs would hang or fail because the dialog blocks execution. A proper implementation should: (1) register a Page.javascriptDialogOpening listener, (2) auto-accept alerts and confirms by default, (3) provide a 'dialog' step type for agents to configure dialog behavior (accept/dismiss, prompt text), and (4) report dialog interactions in the response. This is a significant gap for browser automation - native dialogs are common in legacy web apps.

Click on form submit button that triggers page navigation returns an error 'Cannot find context with specified id' even though the click was successful. The issue is that post-click processing (likely snapshot/changes diff) tries to evaluate JavaScript in the old execution context which was destroyed by the form submission navigation. The click should detect navigation and gracefully handle context destruction instead of bubbling up as an error. This affects test reliability because the step reports 'error' status even though the action succeeded.

No built-in file upload step. File upload via CDP requires DOM.setFileInputFiles which needs protocol-level access. Currently, the workaround is to use DataTransfer API in pageFunction, which works but is fragile (some sites may block synthetic file creation). A dedicated 'upload' step that uses DOM.setFileInputFiles would be more reliable and easier for agents to use.

The upload_area_present milestone has an end-state validation problem. It checks for #drag-drop-upload or #file-upload on the final page, but after successful upload the page navigates to a success page that doesn't have these elements. This milestone can only pass if verified before the upload action, not as a final-state check.

feedback.title: get step with mode:'text' (or default) fails on non-table/non-list elements
feedback.detail: The `get` step routes mode:'text' and default (no mode) to executeExtract(), which only handles 'table' and 'list' data types. When the target element is plain text (e.g., a div containing an h4), executeExtract fails with 'Could not detect data type'. The mode parameter from the get step is completely ignored by executeExtract - it only checks params.type (expecting 'table'|'list'). The get step should return el.textContent for mode:'text' but has no code path to do so. This forces agents to use pageFunction as a workaround for simple text extraction, defeating the purpose of the unified get step. File: cdp-skill/src/runner/execute-form.js lines 38-163 and cdp-skill/src/runner/step-executors.js lines 413-416.

CDP click on the 'edit' link in row 5 was intercepted and fell back to jsClick-auto. The link is a simple <a href='#edit'> with no overlay or pointer-events issue visible. The auto-force jsClick fallback worked correctly, but it may indicate the click target coordinates calculation is slightly off or the element was obscured by the scroll positioning. The table link targets are small (23x16px) which could contribute to coordinate precision issues. Not a bug per se, but worth monitoring whether small inline link elements in table cells consistently trigger the jsClick fallback.

The click step with {text: '10:00', scrollUntilVisible: true} failed to find 10:00 in the time picker's list items. The text-based element search does not match text inside <li> elements within a datepicker's time list. The workaround was using {selector: 'li.react-datepicker__time-list-item', text: '10:00'} which used jsClick-fallback. This suggests the text-matching logic may not search within list items that are scrolled out of view inside a scrollable container within the viewport. The element was technically in the DOM but inside a scrollable sub-container, and the text-based search couldn't find it even with scrollUntilVisible.

The newTab step reported a phantom newTabs entry for an unrelated tab (progress-bar page). This appears to be a tab that was already open and detected as 'new' during the click action. Minor false positive in newTabs detection.

feedback.title: React Select dropdowns consistently trigger jsClick-auto fallback because CDP cl
feedback.detail: React Select dropdowns consistently trigger jsClick-auto fallback because CDP clicks are intercepted. This happens for all 3 React Select containers (s1e3, s1e4, s1e8). The underlying issue is that React Select renders a small invisible input inside a larger container div, and CDP clicks on the input coordinates get intercepted by the overlay container. The auto-fallback works reliably, but it means every React Select interaction logs a warning. Consider detecting React Select containers and using jsClick directly to avoid the warning noise.

feedback.title: The poll step took ~15.6 seconds to detect 25% progress on demoqa's progress bar
feedback.detail: The poll step took ~15.6 seconds to detect 25% progress on demoqa's progress bar. The progress bar increments by 1% per second, so reaching 25% takes ~25 seconds. The poll with 200ms interval worked correctly but the overall latency between poll resolution (at 25%) and the click Stop action allowed the bar to advance to 35%. This is expected behavior given the inherent latency of round-tripping through the CLI between poll completion and the next click command. For timing-critical scenarios, a combined poll+click in a single pageFunction would be more precise, but the current step-based approach worked within the acceptable range.

feedback.detail: The poll step reliably detected the progress bar value using aria-valuenow attribute. feedback.title: fill with CSS selector fails with 'Coordinates must be non-negative' when page is scrolled
feedback.detail: On checkout-step-one.html, after navigating from the cart page, the scroll position carried over (scrollY=208, 100% of page). Calling fill with selector '[data-test=firstName]' failed with 'Coordinates must be non-negative'. The element was visible in the viewport snapshot but the coordinate calculation returned negative values, likely because the scroll offset from the previous page was preserved while the new page's layout was different. Workaround: scroll to top first, then use refs. The fill step's actionability checks should either auto-scroll or handle the coordinate calculation correctly when the scroll position is inherited from a previous navigation.
